title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: First, let’s make sure understand basic functionality x3pPlot(). section discuss arguments x3pPlot() expose underlying ggplot2 functionality change output. Experts ggplot2 can ignore arguments simply adding (+) desired changes ggplot2 object returned x3pPlot(). sections one show can extend functionality x3pPlot() using ggplot2. x3pPlot function takes first argument(s) sequence list x3p objects. code demonstrates mean “sequence” can separated commas. see output visualizes surface values two x3p objects color scale using faceting. specified, facet labels set x3p[0-9]{1,} number x3p objects passed.  Wrapping objects within list() provides exact output.1
code: library(impressions) library(ggplot2)  data("K013sA1") data("K013sA2") x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2) # exact same output as above, so not shown: # x3pPlot(list(K013sA1, K013sA2))

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: arguments x3pPlot() change characteristics plot. First, can change facet labels; either setting x3p.names object passing named list. Note x3p.names ignored named list used.
code: x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,x3p.names = c("Scan A","Scan B")) # exact same output as above, so not shown: # x3pPlot(list("Scan A" = K013sA1, "Scan B" = K013sA2))

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: output argument specifies whether x3p objects visualized color scale using faceting, x3p object visualized color scale output list. former useful comparing surface values across two scans. latter output useful x3p objects whose surface values different scales, meaning one scan’s surface values “drown ” others.
code: x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,output = "list") #> $x3p1 #>  #> $x3p2

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: default, color scheme used x3pPlot() mapping x3p object surface value quantiles divergent purple, white, orange color scale. median surface value mapped white (technically light gray) values /median mapped progressively darker shades purple/orange, respectively. na.value argument set "gray65" default. image summarizes mapping 11 surface quantiles hexidecimal colors. chose mapping found highlighted distinguishable markings cartridge case surface well.  height.colors height.quantiles arguments allow change color scale quantile mapping. example, code maps equally-spaced quantiles grayscale. color scale doesn’t distinguish values median surface value. also change na.value argument illustration.
code: x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,         height.colors = paste0("gray",seq(0,100,by = 10)),         height.quantiles = seq(0,1,by = .1),         na.value = "red")

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: Keen eyes may twitching plot legends previous examples. tick marks plot legend spaced first, second, third quartile labels bunched-overlapping. can give legend quantile labels breathing room using legend.quantiles argument. can also adjust legend length using legend.length argument, internally passed barheight argument guide_colorbar().
code: x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,         legend.quantiles = c(0,.01,.5,.99,1),         legend.length = grid::unit(1,"in"))

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: ’ve already discussed can redefine quantile color scale mapping x3pPlot() function. want change color scale isn’t based quantiles, can simply overwrite old color scale using choice scale_fill_* function. scale_fill_gradient2() example illustrates previous quantile mapping useful – surface values aren’t extreme distinguishable, quantile mapping makes less populous, interesting impressions visible. Note get warning overwriting previous color scale can suppress wrapping visualization call suppressWarning(print(...))
code: plt <- x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,legend.length = grid::unit(1,"in"))  plt +    scale_fill_gradient2(low = "purple",mid = "white",high = "darkorange",midpoint = 0) #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale.

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: legend can changed using theme() /guide_colorbar() .
code: plt +   theme(legend.position = "bottom") +   guides(fill = guide_colourbar(barwidth = grid::unit(2,"in"),                                 barheight = grid::unit(.1,"in"),                                 title = "New Title",                                 title.position = "bottom",                                 label.position = "top",                                 label.theme = element_text(size = 6,                                                                     angle = 90),                                 title.theme = element_text(size = 8),                                 frame.colour = "white",                                 ticks.colour = "white"))

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: hide axis information default. However might want include axis text ticks. can add new theme plot override previous settings. prefer theme_minimal(), .  Note axis text shows pixel-wise increments default. instead want show physical size scan, say micrometers (“microns” \(\mu\)m short), ’ll need information scan resolution. example, scans K013sA1 K013sA2 lateral resolution approximately \(7.4 \times 10^{-6}\) meters, 7.4 micrometers, per pixel can see incrementY (incrementX) element x3p objects. use scale_x_continuous() scale_y_continuous() change axis labels micron scale. Notice use expression() function \(\mu\)m abbreviation. see scans approximately 3000 \(\mu\)m directions.
code: plt +   theme_minimal() K013sA1$header.info$incrementY #same as incrementX #> [1] 7.37364e-06 # K013sA2$header.info$incrementY # same as above  plt +   theme_minimal() +   scale_x_continuous(labels = function(x) round(x*K013sA1$header.info$incrementX*1e6)) +   scale_y_continuous(labels = function(y) round(y*K013sA1$header.info$incrementY*1e6)) +   labs(x = expression("Horizontal Extent ["*mu*"m]"),        y = expression("Vertical Extent ["*mu*"m]"))

title: Using and tweaking x3pPlot()
text: Faceting allows multiple x3p objects visualized color scale, makes easier compare surface values. can change nature faceting adding facet_wrap() facet_grid(), overwrite previous settings. Within x3pPlot() function, convert x3p object data frame add column called x3p tracks label associated scan. can facet plot x3p column. example , can see output changes depending faceting function used.   can also change facet labeling using labeller() example .
code: plt +   facet_wrap(~x3p,ncol = 1) plt +   facet_grid(rows = vars(x3p)) plt +   facet_wrap(~ x3p,              labeller = labeller(x3p = c(x3p1 = "Scan A",                                          x3p2 = "Scan B"),                                  .default = function(string) toupper(string)))

title: Authors and Citation
text: Joseph Zemmels. Author, maintainer. Heike Hofmann. Author. Susan VanderPlas. Author. CSAFE. Funder.            Center Statistics Applications Forensic Evidence

title: Authors and Citation
text: Zemmels J, Hofmann H, VanderPlas S (2023). impressions: Diagnose Cartridge Case Comparison Algorithms. R package version 0.1.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {impressions: Diagnose Cartridge Case Comparison Algorithms},   author = {Joseph Zemmels and Heike Hofmann and Susan VanderPlas},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0}, }

title: Diagnose cartridge case comparison algorithms
text: R package diagnosing cartridge case impression comparison algorithms.

title: Diagnose cartridge case comparison algorithms
text: can install development version impressions GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("jzemmels/impressions")

title: Diagnose cartridge case comparison algorithms
text: example, consider two cartridge cases fired Ruger SR9 semiautomatic 9-mm handgun. Learn collection cartridge cases . cartridge cases uniquely identified “K013sA1” “K013sA2.” assume markings cartridge cases left handgun firing process similar. visual two cartridge case scans. Note scans already undergone preprocessing emphasize breech face impression markings. similarity cartridge cases immediately apparent. color scheme plots chosen highlight extreme values (far median value) scan, meaning small, local similarities highlighted. can use visual diagnostics available impressions package understand similarity scans.
code: library(impressions)  library(cmcR) library(tidyverse)  data("K013sA1","K013sA2") x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,         x3pNames = c("Scan A","Scan B"))

title: Diagnose cartridge case comparison algorithms
text: comparison plot powerful tool separate two cartridge case scans “similar” “different” regions. First, attempt align two scans rotating translating K013sA2 match K013sA1. use cmcR::comparison_allTogether() function estimate alignment. sake example, ’ll consider K013sA2 rotated 3 degrees translated maximize cross-correlation function K013sA1. resulting comparisonData data frame contains transformed version scan K013sA2 rotating/translating align K013sA1. ’ll pass transformed scan x3p2 argument.
code: comparisonData <- cmcR::comparison_allTogether(K013sA1,K013sA2,                                                theta = 3,                                                numCells = c(1,1),                                                maxMissingProp = .99,                                                sideLengthMultiplier = 1.1,                                                returnX3Ps = TRUE) x3p_comparisonPlot(x3p1 = comparisonData$cellHeightValues[[1]],                    x3p2 = comparisonData$alignedTargetCell[[1]],                    legendLength = grid::unit(6,"in"),                    legendQuantiles = c(0,.01,.05,.5,.95,.99,1))

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: See magrittr::%>% details.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
code: lhs %>% rhs

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: lhs value magrittr placeholder. rhs function call using magrittr semantics.

title: Pipe operator — %>%
text: result calling `rhs(lhs)`.

what: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
title: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
text: x3p_elemAverage() calculate element-wise average two surface matrices (dimensions) x3p_sd() Calculate standard deviation x3p surface values x3p_filter() replace values surface matrix based element-wise conditional function x3p_cropWS() Crop rows/columns missing values around x3p x3p_to_dataFrame() Convert x3p object data frame x3p_delete() replace values surface matrix NA depending associated mask.

title: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
code: x3p_elemAverage(x3p1, x3p2)  x3p_sd(..., na.rm = TRUE)  x3p_filter(x3p, cond, replacement = NA, ...)  x3p_cropWS(x3p, croppingThresh = 1)  x3p_to_dataFrame(x3p, preserveResolution = FALSE)  x3p_delete(x3p, mask_vals)

title: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
text: x3p1 x3p object x3p2 another x3p object ... one x3p objects na.rm logical. missing values removed? x3p x3p object cond Boolean function whose first argument `x`. replacement value replace element cond returns FALSE croppingThresh minimum number non-NA pixels need row/column cropped surface matrix preserveResolution Boolean dictating whether scan resolution preserved returned data frame. FALSE, x,y data frame columns integer-valued. Otherwise, difference consecutive x,y values equal scan resolution. mask_vals hexidecimal color value corresponds indices mask whose indices replaced associated surface

title: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
text: Transform values x3p surface matrix

title: Transform x3p surface matrix values — x3p_elemAverage
code: data("K013sA1","K013sA2")  # calculates the sd for a single x3p's surface values x3p_sd(K013sA1) #> [1] 1.3624  # calculates the sd for the joint surface values for two x3ps x3p_sd(K013sA1,K013sA2) #> [1] 1.336353  # calculate optimal alignment between the two x3ps K013sA2_aligned <- cmcR::comparison_allTogether(K013sA1,K013sA2,theta = -3,                                                 returnX3Ps = TRUE,numCells = c(1,1),                                                 maxMissingProp = .99)$alignedTargetCell[[1]]  averaged <- x3p_elemAverage(K013sA1,K013sA2_aligned)  # this will replace values that are larger (in magnitude) than one standard # deviation of the input x3p's surface values with NA: filtered1 <- x3p_filter(K013sA1,                         cond = function(x,thresh) x < thresh,                         thresh = x3p_sd(K013sA1))  # this will replace all surface matrix values between -1 and 1 with 0 filtered2 <- x3p_filter(K013sA1,cond = function(x) abs(x) < 1,replacement = 0)  # exaggerated cropping for the sake of an example cropped <- x3p_cropWS(K013sA1,croppingThresh = 100)  x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2_aligned,averaged,filtered1,filtered2,cropped,         x3pNames = c("K01sA1","K013sA2 Aligned","Averaged","Filtered1","Filtered2","Cropped")) #> Error in purrr::map_chr(x3pList, class): ℹ In index: 2. #> ℹ With name: surface.matrix. #> Caused by error: #> ! Result must be length 1, not 2.

what: Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
title: Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
text: Plots surface matrices list x3p objects. Either  creates one plot faceted surface matrix creates individual plots per  surface matrix returns list.

title: Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
text: ... one x3p objects x3p.names character vector containing names x3p object output dictates whether one plot faceted surface matrix list plots per surface matrix returned. faceted plot consistent height scale across surface matrices. height.colors vector colors passed scale_fill_gradientn dictates height value colorscale height.quantiles vector quantiles associated color defined height.colors argument legend.quantiles vector quantiles shown tick marks legend plot na.value color used NA values (passed scale_fill_gradientn) legend.length length plot legend. Passed barheight argument ggplot2::guide_colorbar function

title: Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
text: ggplot object list ggplot objects showing surface matrix  height values.

title: Plot a list of x3ps — x3pPlot
code: data("K013sA1","K013sA2")  x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,x3p.names = c("Scan A","Scan B"))

what:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
title:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
text: Plot filtered element-wise average differences two cartridge case scans

title:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
code: x3p_comparisonPlot(   x3p1,   x3p2,   threshold = 1,   plotLabels = c("x3p1", "x3p2", "Element-wise Average", "x3p1 diff.", "x3p2 diff."),   showOutlines = TRUE,   labelSize = 4,   label_x = ncol(x3p1$surface.matrix)/2,   label_y = nrow(x3p1$surface.matrix)/2,   type = "faceted",   legendLength = grid::unit(3, "in"),   legendUnit = "Norm.",   legendHoriz = -1.2,   legendQuantiles = c(0, 0.01, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.99, 1) )

title:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
text: x3p1 x3p object x3p2 another x3p object threshold default filtering threshold. Defaults scalar (1 micron = 1e-6 meters), can also set scalar-valued function takes x3p1 x3p2 arguments. example, threshold = impressions::x3p_sd use joint standard deviation x3p1 x3p2 threshold. plotLabels character vector five elements display labels plot showOutlines boolean value whether show outline around filtered elements element-wise average difference plots. See notes details labelSize font size plot labels label_x horizontal location plot labels label_y vertical location plot labels type return five plots single, faceted plot list legendLength length plot legend. Passed barwidth argument ggplot2::guide_colorbar function legendUnit unit measurement surface values (typically either "micron" "Norm.") legendHoriz horizontal location legend. Passed patchwork::inset_element function legendQuantiles quantile values shown legend labels. Passed within breaks argument ggplot2::scale_fill_gradientn function

title:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
text: showOutlines argument set FALSE sidesteps computation   outlines filtered regions comparison plot.   systems, particularly Linux systems, may necessary   libraries required compute outline installed default.   Specifically, function compute outlines relies R package   called rgeos (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/rgeos/index.html),   API geos geometry engine (https://libgeos.org/). Linux   users need install geos install rgeos compute outline. See   post info:   https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53389181/installing--r-package-rgeos--linux-geos-config--found---executab   Alternatively, can skip outline calculation together using   showOutlines argument expense seeing region   outlines, nice visual aid necessary component   plot.

title:
Plot filtered element-wise average and differences for two cartridge case
scans — x3p_comparisonPlot
code: data("K013sA1","K013sA2")  compData <- cmcR::comparison_allTogether(reference = K013sA1,                                          target = K013sA2,                                          theta = 3,numCells = c(1,1),                                          maxMissingProp = .99,                                          sideLengthMultiplier = 1.1,                                          returnX3Ps = TRUE)  x3p_comparisonPlot(x3p1 = compData$cellHeightValues[[1]],x3p2 = compData$alignedTargetCell[[1]]) #> Regions defined for each Polygons #> Warning: Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: colour #> Warning: Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: colour #> Warning: Duplicated aesthetics after name standardisation: colour #> Warning: Raster pixels are placed at uneven horizontal intervals and will be shifted #> ℹ Consider using `geom_tile()` instead. #> Warning: Raster pixels are placed at uneven horizontal intervals and will be shifted #> ℹ Consider using `geom_tile()` instead. #> Warning: Raster pixels are placed at uneven horizontal intervals and will be shifted #> ℹ Consider using `geom_tile()` instead. #> Warning: Raster pixels are placed at uneven horizontal intervals and will be shifted #> ℹ Consider using `geom_tile()` instead.

what: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
title: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
text: Crop rows/columns missing values around x3p

title: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
code: x3p_cropWS(x3p, croppingThresh = 1, ...)

title: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
text: x3p x3p object containing surface matrix croppingThresh minimum number non-NA pixels need row/column cropped surface matrix crop

title: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
text: surface matrix outer rows/columns removed depending   croppingThresh

title: Crop rows/columns of missing values around an x3p — x3p_cropWS
code: data("K013sA1")  x3pCropped <- x3p_cropWS(K013sA1,croppingThresh = 5)  x3pPlot(K013sA1,x3pCropped)

text: Replace elements surface matrix based mask

title: Replace elements of a surface matrix based on a mask — x3p_delete
code: x3p_delete(x3p, mask_vals, replacement = NA)

title: Replace elements of a surface matrix based on a mask — x3p_delete
text: x3p x3p object mask_vals hexidecimal color value corresponds indices mask whose indices replaced associated surface matrix replacement value used replace indices surface matrix

what: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
title: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
text: Calculates element-wise average surface values   two x3ps (dimension)

title: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
code: x3p_elemAverage(x3p1, x3p2)

title: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
text: x3p1 x3p object x3p2 another x3p object

title: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
text: x3p object containing element-wise average surface   values x3p1 x3p1

title: Calculate the element-wise average between two x3ps — x3p_elemAverage
code: data("K013sA1","K013sA2")  ave1 <- x3p_elemAverage(K013sA1,K013sA2) #> Error in x3p_elemAverage(K013sA1, K013sA2): all(dim(x3p1$surface.matrix) == dim(x3p2$surface.matrix)) is not TRUE  x3pPlot(K013sA1,K013sA2,ave1) #> Error in x3pPlot(K013sA1, K013sA2, ave1): object 'ave1' not found

what: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
text: Filters elements x3p surface matrix replacing values  based element-wise conditional (Boolean) function

title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
code: x3p_filter(x3p, cond, replacement = NA, ...)

title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
text: x3p x3p object cond Boolean function whose first argument `x`. replacement value replace element cond returns FALSE ... additional arguments cond function

title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
text: x3p object containing filtered version input x3p's surface  matrix

title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
text: value returned cond function length  total number elements surface matrix (e.g., use vectorized  operations)

title: Filter a surface matrix by an element-wise conditional function — x3p_filter
code: data("K013sA1")  # this will replace values that are larger (in magnitude) than one standard # deviation of the input x3p's surface values with NA: filtered1 <- x3p_filter(K013sA1,                         cond = function(x,thresh) x < thresh,                         thresh = x3p_sd(K013sA1))  # this will replace all surface matrix values between -1 and 1 with 0 filtered2 <- x3p_filter(K013sA1,cond = function(x) abs(x) > 1,replacement = 0)  x3pPlot(K013sA1,filtered1,filtered2,         x3pNames = c("K01sA1","filtered1","filtered2"),         type = "list") #> $K01sA1  #>  #> $filtered1  #>  #> $filtered2 #> Warning: collapsing to unique 'x' values #> Warning: collapsing to unique 'x' values #> Warning: collapsing to unique 'x' values  #>

what: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
title: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
text: Calculates standard deviation surface values one   x3p objects

title: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
code: x3p_sd(..., na.rm = TRUE)

title: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
text: ... one x3p objects na.rm logical. missing values removed?

title: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
text: standard deviation input surface matrices

title: Calculate the standard deviation of x3p surface values — x3p_sd
code: data("K013sA1","K013sA2")  # calculates the sd for a single x3p's surface values x3p_sd(K013sA1) #> [1] 1.3624  # calculates the sd for the joint surface values for two x3ps x3p_sd(K013sA1,K013sA2) #> [1] 1.336353

what: Convert an x3p object to a data frame — x3p_to_dataFrame
title: Convert an x3p object to a data frame — x3p_to_dataFrame
text: Convert x3p object data frame

title: Convert an x3p object to a data frame — x3p_to_dataFrame
code: x3p_to_dataFrame(x3p, preserveResolution = FALSE)

title: Convert an x3p object to a data frame — x3p_to_dataFrame
text: x3p x3p object preserveResolution boolean dictating whether scan resolution preserved returned data frame. FALSE, x,y data frame columns integer-valued. Otherwise, difference consecutive x,y values equal scan resolution.
